content.webTitle: Pre-budget report: what the opposition wants

fields.headline: Pre-budget report: what the opposition wants
fields.bodyText: Conservative party It's time for a change of direction. The burden of regulation, having risen, should now fall - so that companies can focus on driving up productivity. Savings, which Gordon Brown has penalised, should now be encouraged - so that people can feel secure as they approach retirement. Most of all, the government needs to accept that real reform of the public services is required to deliver the improvements everyone wants to see. Labour's 60 tax rises and extra spending have not delivered the higher standards we were promised in return. We need to leave public service professionals free to manage. And we need to make them accountable to choices made not by bureaucrats but by the people they chose to serve. Liberal Democrats The Liberal Democrats would tax incomes over £100,000 a year at 50%. We would also scrap the unfair council tax and replace it with a local income tax based on ability to pay. Money raised from taxing incomes over £100k at 50% would pay for three things only: · Scraping tuition and top-up fees for students · Introducing free personal care for the elderly · Keeping down the rate of local taxes We would also raise around £5bn by switching money from lower priority programmes to our priorities, such as by cutting the DTI budget. We would spend that money on the people and frontline services who need it the most. Caroline Lucas, Green party The Green party would: · Benefit low and average earners by abolishing VAT and increasing income tax on our highest earners · Introduce a non-means-tested citizens' income to replace existing benefits · Scrap means-testing for pensioners · Abolish tuition fees and reintroduce student grants, funded from taxation · Use fuel tax to fund an energy efficiency programme to reduce domestic energy use by 30% within 10 years &149; Put 6p on a litre of petrol, but abolish tax discs, leaving typical motorists with smaller cars £30 a year better off · End aviation's £9.2bn annual tax break and scrap the £30bn roads programme, to fund public transport.
